paper_id: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments

paper_metadata.title: Balance of potassium in two long-term field experiments with different fertilization treatments
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium balance and related changes in soil under different fertilization treatments in long-term field experiments

research_methodology.experimental_design: Long-term stationary field experiments (21 years) with 6 fertilization treatments and a 3-crop rotation (potatoes-winter wheat-spring barley). All three crops were grown each year. Soil samples were taken from plots with spring barley.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Annually for plant harvest; soil samples in 1996 (before experiment) and 2017 (after 7th crop rotation)
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Autumn (October) for organic fertilizers (FYM, straw) and mineral P/K; Spring for mineral N (potatoes, spring barley); Split N dose for winter wheat (BBCH 21, BBCH 31-32)

spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Intensive farming systems used in the Czech Republic

sample_design.randomization_approach: Not explicitly stated, but implied by 'stationary field experiments'
controls_and_treatments: Half dose of farmyard manure + nitrogen (N) in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (FYM 1/2)
Straw of spring barley + N in mineral nitrogen fertilizers (N + ST)

measurement_protocols: Soil samples: air-dried, ≤ 2 mm, 0–30 cm depth
Plant samples: dried at 40°C, dry decomposition (Mader et al. 1998)
CaCl2/DTPA (CAT) extraction (CSN EN 13651, 2001): 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 0.01 mol/L CaCl2 and 0.002 mol/L DTPA, shaken 1 h
Mehlich 3 extraction (Mehlich 1984): 3.00 g soil + 30 mL solution (0.02 mol/L CH3COOH, 0.25 mol/L NH4NO3, 0.015 mol/L NH4F, 0.013 mol/L HNO3, 0.001 mol/L EDTA), shaken 5 min
Ammonium acetate (NH4OAc) extraction (Haby et al. 1990 modified): 3.00 g soil + 30 mL 1 mol/L ammonium acetate (pH 7.00), shaken 2 h, centrifugation
Boiling HNO3 extraction (Helmke and Sparks 2000): 2.5 g finely ground soil + 25 mL 1 mol/L HNO3, heated 10 min after boiling, filtered, diluted to 100 mL with 0.1 mol/L HNO3
instrumentation: Optical emission spectrometer with inductive coupled plasma (ICP-OES, Agilent Technologies 700, Victoria, Australia) for soil extracts
Atomic adsorption spectrometry (AA280FS, Agilent Technologies, Mulgrave, Australia) for plant K content
quality_control: Not explicitly detailed beyond standard methods

statistical_approach.significance_testing: Statistically significant differences (p-values provided for correlations)

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St); Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St)
Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St); Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St)

statistical_measures.measurement_context: Humpolec K uptake higher by 348 kg K/ha on average for all variants compared to Hněvčeves

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St); Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + St)

primary_measurements.parameter: Potassium recovery rate from farmyard manure by crops
Potassium recovery rate from mineral fertilizers by crops
Exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (NH4OAc)
Non-exchangeable potassium content in plough layer (Boiling HNO3 - Kex)
Saturation of potassium in cation exchange capacity (CEC)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Hněvčeves (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST); Humpolec (Control, FYM 1, FYM 1/2, N, NPK, N + ST)

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Significant tendency to decrease at Hněvčeves (Luvisol) in variants without K fertilization. No significant impact at Humpolec (Cambisol).

comparative_results.practical_significance: Higher yields of cereals at Hněvčeves, higher yields of potatoes at Humpolec; higher K uptake at Humpolec despite lower bioavailable K in soil, possibly due to higher precipitation and distribution.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Fertilization treatment effects on K balance
comparative_results.practical_significance: Positive K balance only with manure fertilization (FYM 1). Maximum negative balance with mineral N fertilization (-2376 kg K/ha/21 years at Humpolec).

comparative_results.comparison_type: Changes in K content in plough layer (1996-2017)
comparative_results.statistical_significance: Not explicitly stated for individual changes, but overall trends are discussed.
comparative_results.practical_significance: K amount in plough layer decreased in all unfertilized variants. Highest decrease recorded at mineral N fertilization variant.

geographic_details.elevation: Hněvčeves: 265 m a.s.l.; Humpolec: 525 m a.s.l.

precipitation_patterns.distribution: Regular distribution throughout the vegetation period at Humpolec

soil_properties.soil_classification: Hněvčeves: Haplic Luvisol; Humpolec: Stagnic Cambisol
soil_properties.texture: Hněvčeves: Clay loam; Humpolec: Sandy loam
soil_properties.mineralogy: Hněvčeves: on loess; Humpolec: on loess on paragneiss (implying different clay mineral types, e.g., 2:1 types, mica, vermiculite)

sustainability_metrics: Changes in exchangeable and non-exchangeable K

timing: Organic fertilizers (FYM, ST) applied in autumn (October) to potatoes
Mineral P and K fertilizers applied to each crop in autumn
Mineral N fertilizers applied to potatoes and spring barley in spring prior to crop establishment
Winter wheat N dose divided into halves (BBCH 21, BBCH 31–32)

data_collection_schedule: Soil samples: 1996 (autumn, before experiment), 2017 (after plant harvest)
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Annual for plant yields and K content; biennial for soil K content (implied by 1996 and 2017 samples)

long_term_trends.parameter: Non-exchangeable K content in plough layer
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Decrease observed at Hněvčeves (Luvisol) in variants without K fertilization, indicating reliance on non-exchangeable K. No significant change at Humpolec (Cambisol) due to higher initial content and potential release.
Decreased in all unfertilized variants. Highest decrease with mineral N fertilization. Indicates K deficit in agricultural soils with insufficient K fertilization.
Decreased in all unfertilized variants. Highest decrease with mineral N fertilization.
Decreased in all unfertilized variants. Highest decrease with mineral N fertilization.

inter_annual_variability.crop_yields: Higher yields of cereals at Hněvčeves, higher yields of potatoes at Humpolec
inter_annual_variability.K_uptake: Higher K uptake at Humpolec (by 348 kg K/ha on average) possibly due to higher precipitation and its regular distribution

spatial_variability.soil_properties: Significant differences between Hněvčeves (Luvisol) and Humpolec (Cambisol) in soil texture, pH, CEC, and K fractions.

drivers_of_variability: Crop rotation and specific crop K uptake

methodological_strengths: Long-term (21 years) field experiments provide valuable insights into long-term nutrient dynamics.
Two sites with different soil and climatic conditions enhance the generalizability of findings.
Comprehensive analysis of different potassium fractions (bioavailable, exchangeable, non-exchangeable) provides a holistic view.
Comparison of multiple extraction methods for K determination.
methodological_limitations: Soil analyses for the manuscript were based only on samples taken from plots with spring barley, which might not fully represent the entire crop rotation effect.
K balance calculations did not consider K content in the subsoil, which can be a significant potassium source for plants.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: High, detailed quantitative data provided for K balance, soil K fractions, plant K content, yields, and soil characteristics.

measurement_precision.analytical_methods_detailed: Yes, specific methods and instrumentation are listed.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Two distinct sites in the Czech Republic provide good spatial coverage for the region.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: 21-year study duration provides robust long-term trends.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Crop rotation corresponds to intensive farming systems in the Czech Republic.

uncertainty_sources: Exclusion of subsoil K in balance calculations may lead to underestimation of K availability.
Continuous mobilization of non-exchangeable K is a complex process not fully captured by simple balance equations.
validation_evidence: Results are compared with findings from other long-term experiments (e.g., Blake et al. 1999, Liu et al. 2010, Srinivvasarao et al. 2014).

key_methodological_references: Egnér H., Riehm H., Domingo W.R. (1960): Egner-Riehm method
Mehlich A. (1984): Mehlich 3 soil test extractant
Haby V.A., Russelle M.P., Skogley E.O. (1990): Ammonium acetate extraction
Helmke P.A., Sparks D.L. (2000): Boiling HNO3 extraction
Mader P., Száková J., Miholová D. (1998): Dry ashing of biological materials
comparative_studies: Blake L. et al. (1999): Potassium content in soil, uptake in plants and K balance in European long-term field experiments
Liu E. et al. (2010): Long-term effect of chemical fertilizer, straw, and manure on soil chemical and biological properties
Srinivasarao Ch. et al. (2014): Potassium release characteristics, K balance, and fingermillet yield sustainability
Binner I. et al. (2017): Potassium adsorption and release properties of clays
Øgaard A.F., Krogstad T. (2005): Ability of different soil extraction methods to predict potassium release
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Potassium cycling in soil, plant uptake of exchangeable and non-exchangeable K, K fixation by clay minerals (2:1 types, mica, vermiculite), rhizosphere processes (H+ excretion)
benchmarking_data: Comparison of K pool assessment in CR for loamy soils ('satisfactory pool' or 'good pool')
Comparison of non-exchangeable K contents with Bad Lauchstadt and Rothamsted long-term trials (Blake et al. 1999)

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in quantitative data, especially regarding K balances, soil K fractions, and site characteristics. It provides detailed methodological information.
potential_ambiguities: Some specific values from figures were described qualitatively in the text (e.g., 'average value of all treatments reached 200 mg K/kg') rather than providing exact values for each treatment from the figure itself. However, the key numerical data from tables are precise.
Statistical significance levels (p-values) are not provided for all comparative results, only for correlations.
extraction_limitations: The prompt's 'Available Tables' section was misleading and contained OCR output from figures, not actual structured tables. The extraction relied solely on the paper's text and its embedded tables.
quality_flags: High detail for methodology and quantitative results.
Clear distinction between sites and treatments.
recommended_validation_checks: Cross-reference all numerical values from the JSON with the original paper's tables and text to ensure accuracy.
Verify the interpretation of 'changes' vs. 'contents' for K fractions.
